sect1.title: 129 Fungi Causing Eumycotic Mycetoma
sect1.para: WENDY W. J. VAN DE SANDE

Eumycetoma was recognized as a neglected tropical disease by the World Health Organization in 2016. It is a chronic, granulomatous, progressive subcutaneous fungal disease characterized by the production of large masses of fungal material called grains, which are discharged through sinus tracts. Eumycetoma is seen more frequently in tropical and subtropical regions and is rare in temperate countries, where it usually occurs among immigrants from the tropics. Several hyaline and dematiaceous fungi can cause eumycetoma, and their distributions are greatly affected by climate, especially rainfall, and by socioeconomic conditions.

sect2.title: TAXONOMY AND DESCRIPTION OF THE AGENTS
sect2.para: All fungi known to cause eumycetoma belong to the phylum Ascomycota. Although for many species no ascus-producing state is known (1), their phylogenetic affiliation has been proven by DNA sequencing. Ordinal relationships are hypothesized on the basis of ribosomal small subunit (1) and internal transcribed spacer (ITS) DNA sequences (2) (Table 1; see also listing by order below). The etiologic agents described in this chapter are species that are isolated most commonly from human or lower-animal eumycetoma. For species that are implicated as rare causative agents of eumycetoma but are more common in other conditions, please refer to the corresponding chapters in this Manual.

sect2.title: Madurella Species
sect2.para: Madurella mycetomatis is the most common fungal causative agent of eumycetoma (3, 4) (Fig. 1A, B, and C). It is common in the arid climatic zone of Africa (Sudan, Mali, and Djibouti), and it is occasionally encountered in the Middle East and India. The taxonomy of M. mycetomatis was proved by a number of phylogenetic studies in which DNA sequences of the mitochondrial genome, the ribosomal DNA (rDNA) ITS, the beta-tubulin gene (BT2), and the RNA polymerase II subunit gene (RPB2) were determined (1, 5, 6). The complete genome (GenBank accession number LCTW00000000) has been sequenced for Sudanese isolate Mm55, which has been deposited in the CBS-KNAW fungal collection of the Westerdijk Fungal Biodiversity Institute under the number CBS 131320 (7). Three additional genome sequences were sequenced for Sudanese isolates NMM13 (GenBank accession number WOGW00000000), NMM15 (WOGY00000000), and NMM18 (GenBank accession number WOGX00000000) (8).

Based on the ITS,BT2, and RPB2 sequences, it appeared that several other species previously misidentified as M. mycetomatis belong to different Madurella species. These new Madurella species include Madurella pseudomycetomatis, M. tropicana, and M. fahalii (5, 9). Of these species, M. fahalii seemed to be more resistant to antifungal agents (5). Since these species can be differentiated only on the basis of molecular identification, it is not clear how many of the previous reported eumycetoma cases attributed to M. mycetomatis might actually have been caused by a different Madurella species. In Sudan, it is likely that the majority of eumycetoma cases morphologically identified as M. mycetomatis are indeed caused by M. mycetomatis, as Ahmed et al. demonstrated with ITS sequencing that only 2 out of 67 M. mycetomatis suspected black-grain eumycetomata were caused by another Madurella species, namely, one by M. tropicana and one by M. fahalii (10). However, in Mexico, most M. mycetomatis suspected cases were due to M. pseudomycetomatis (11). Next to Mexico (11), M. pseudomycetomatis has been identified in Italy (12), Venezuela (13), Iran (8), and China (9). M. tropicana was identified in Sudan (10) and Indonesia (5).

sect1.title: Order Pleosporales
sect1.para: Falciformispora senegalensis (Previously Known as Leptosphaeria senegalensis) and Falciformispora tompkinsii (Previously Known as L. tompkinsii)

Based on the combined DNA sequence data set of the small ribosomal subunit (SSU), large ribosomal subunit (LSU),RPB2, and translation elongation factor 1-alpha (TEF1) genes, Leptosphaeria senegalensis and L. tompkinsii were found to cluster in the pleosporalean family Trematosphaeriaceae, with Falciformispora lignatilis as the closest relative. Therefore, L. senegalensis was renamed Falciformispora senegalensis and L. tompkinsii as F. tompkinsii (14). F. senegalensis is a dematiaceous filamentous fungus that produces cleistothecia containing large asci with eight ascospores; each of the ascospores is ellipsoidal, has four septa, and is surrounded by a slime sheath (15) (Fig. 1D, E, and F). F. senegalensis and the related species F. tompkinsii cause eumycetomata in the northern tropical portion of Africa, especially in Senegal and Mauritania, and in India (16–19).

table.title: TABLE 1 Overview of species causing eumycotic eumycetoma

sect1.para: aThe top five most common causative agents are listed according to the number of cases. The more rarely encountered causative agents are listed in alphabetical order.

bNumbers of isolates are from reference 4. In that study, a meta-analysis of 17,607 mycetoma cases was performed. The species identification was unknown for 225 fungi. One should take into consideration that the species identification was based on histology and/or culturing. It is probable that molecular identification would yield different numbers of isolates for each species.
cC, common (>5% of the reported cases worldwide were caused by this species); O, occasional (caused 1 to 5%); R, rare (caused <1%). Data according to references 3 and 4.

sect2.title: Trematosphaeria grisea (Previously Known as Madurella grisea)
sect2.para: In 2004, it was demonstrated by molecular phylogeny and diagnostics that the members of the genusMadurella encompass a hidden diversity beyond the currently recognized species (1). Both an rRNA restriction fragment length polymorphism analysis and a species-specific ITS PCR were used for species distinction by Ahmed et al. (20, 21). Based on the rDNA sequence, the taxonomic position of M. grisea was changed to the order Pleosporales, and therefore, it should no longer be considered a sister species to M. mycetomatis, which is a member of the Sordariales. In 2013, the name was officially changed to Trematosphaeria grisea (9). Based on the combined molecular data set of the SSU gene (18S rDNA), the LSU gene (28S rDNA), RPB2, and TEF1, it was demonstrated that M. grisea formed a well-supported clade with Trematosphaeria pertusa (9); hence the renaming to T. grisea. T. grisea has been reported to occur as an etiologic agent of black-grain eumycetoma in South America, India, Africa, and North and Central America (22–25), but older literature data need verification by sequencing (17). The fungus is a coelomycete, but conidial fruiting bodies may remain absent (Fig. 1G, H, and I). With strictly sterile cultures, molecular confirmation is required for identification, demonstrated by the finding that out of 31 fungal isolates deposited in either the National Collection of Pathogenic Fungi (NCPF, Bristol, United Kingdom) or the Institut Pasteur Culture Collection (UMIP, Paris, France) as M. grisea, 28 were in fact other pleosporalean agents of eumycetoma (Nigrograna mackinnonii, 8 isolates; Medicopsis romeroi, 10 isolates; Rhytidhysteron rufulum, 4 isolates; Emarellia grisea, 5 isolates; Emarellia paragrisea, 1 isolate) (17).

sect2.title: Medicopsis romeroi (Previously Known as Pyrenochaeta romeroi)
sect2.para: Based on sequences of the 18S (small-subunit) rDNA and the 28S (large-subunit) rDNA, it has become clear thatPyrenochaeta romeroi is distantly related to the type species of Pyrenochaeta (Pyrenochaeta nobilis) (26). Therefore, P. romeroi was renamed as Medicopsis romeroi by de Gruyter et al. (27). M. romeroi is a coelomycetous anamorphic fungus. It might be misidentified as T. grisea when cultures lack pycnidia (15). Eumycetomata caused by M. romeroi have been reported from Somalia, Saudi Arabia, India, Pakistan, and South America (17, 28–30). Colony appearance and microscopy of granules and fruiting bodies resemble those of T. grisea. This explains why at least 10 nonsporulating isolates of M. romeroi were misidentified as T. grisea in the past (17).

figure.title: FIGURE 1 Cultures of eumycetoma-causative agents. (A) M. mycetomatis colony on Sabouraud dextrose agar. (B) M. mycetomatis sterile sclerotia. (C) M. mycetomatis phialides and minute conidia. (D) F. senegalensis colony on malt extract agar. (E) F. senegalensis ascomata. (F) F. senegalensis ascospore. (G) T. grisea colony on malt extract agar. (H) T. grisea pycnidia containing conidia. (I) T. grisea conidiophores and conidia. (J) N. rosatii colony on malt extract agar. (K) N. rosatii ascomata. (L) N. rosatii asci and ascospores.

sect2.title: Nigrograna mackinnonii (Previously Known as Pyrenochaeta mackinnonii)
sect2.para: Molecular analysis of the 18S and 28S rRNA genes also revealed thatPyrenochaeta mackinnonii is distant from the type species of Pyrenochaeta (Pyrenochaeta nobilis) (26, 27). Furthermore, M. romeroi (formerly Pyrenochaeta romeroi) and P. mackinnonii were found to be phylogenetically remote from each other, and therefore, P. mackinnonii was assigned to a different genus, Nigrograna, and renamed N. mackinnonii (27, 31). Between 2014 and 2015, this species was named Biatriospora mackinnonii (14), but after a thorough taxonomic revision, it was changed back to N. mackinnonii in 2015 (31). The complete genome of N. mackinnonii has been sequenced from endophytic isolate E5202H, which was deposited in the American Type Culture Collection (ATCC) as SD-6893 (32). N. mackinnonii has been reported as the causative agent of eumycetoma in patients from Costa Rica, Mexico, and Venezuela.

sect2.title: Emarellia grisea and Emarellia paragrisea
sect2.para: Based on the combined DNA sequence data of the LSU (28S rDNA), ITS, actin (ACT), RPB2, and TEF1 genes, it was demonstrated that Emarellia grisea and E. paragrisea clustered among the pleosporalean causative agents of eumycetoma (17). In culture, these fungi produce only sterile, melanized hyphae. E. grisea causes eumycetomata in India and Sri Lanka (17).

sect2.title: Neotestudina rosatii
sect2.para: Neotestudina rosatii has been isolated from soil from tropical countries; it is an ascomycete with spherical, deliquescent asci and rhomboid ascospores with one septum each (15) (Fig. 1J, K, and L). Eumycetomata caused by N. rosatii have been described in Australia, Cameroon, Guinea, Senegal, and Somalia (29, 33).

sect2.title: Scedosporium Species
sect2.para: The genusScedosporium comprises a small group of rather variable species (34–37). The nomenclature of the genera Scedosporium/Pseudallescheria has been revised in the last years. With the establishment of the “One Fungus = One Name” rule in fungal taxonomy, which allows only a single name per fungus, the genus name Scedosporium was retained and Pseudallescheria was abandoned (37). Already in the 1920s the genus was known to cause human eumycetoma (38), mainly in temperate climates (39) and occurring mostly in the limbs (40). Currently, the genus Scedosporium contains at least 10 species (37), of which only S. boydii and S. apiospermum are associated with eumycetoma.

sect1.title: Other Orders
sect1.para: Eumycetoma can be caused by many different fungal species; most of these species are only rarely encountered in eumycetoma (Table 1).

sect2.title: EPIDEMIOLOGY AND TRANSMISSION
sect2.para: The number of species involved in eumycetoma is increasing, but little is known about the epidemiology and mode of transmission of these species. Case reports are indicative of the presence of certain species in particular geographical locations but do not provide a clear understanding of the environmental distribution of species and the possible ecological niches. Only for eumycetoma caused byM. mycetomatis has ecological niche modeling been performed. For that species, the presence of light clay soil, sandy loam soil, or loam soil (42), with a soil calcium concentration between 3 g/kg and 11 g/kg (41), and the presence of Acacia trees (41, 42) were associated with eumycetoma. Also the vicinity of a river was positively correlated (41).

Eumycetoma has been contracted in 102 countries, and reports have been found from every continent except Antarctica (43), but there are large differences in the burden of disease over the globe (3, 4, 43). So far, the highest numbers of cases have been reported from Sudan (3, 4, 43), Mexico, Senegal, and India (3, 4, 19, 43). Countries with a high prevalence were Mauritania (prevalence of 3.49 cases per 100,000 inhabitants) and Sudan (1.81 cases per 100,000 inhabitants) (3). In villages with high endemicity in Sudan, a prevalence of 1 to 5.2 cases per 1,000 inhabitants was found in the 1960s (44) and 6.2 to 35 cases per 1,000 inhabitants in the 2010s (44, 45).

The causal agents of eumycetoma are largely saprobes that live on hard plant materials, such as various types of thorns and spines, that are associated with soil (46–49). Segretain and colleagues (33, 50), using specific isolation media and techniques, showed that F. senegalensis and F. tompkinsii could be recovered from about 50% of the dry thorns of Acacia trees that they examined, particularly those that had been stained by mud during the rainy season. N. rosatii was isolated from sandy soil (29), and M. mycetomatis was isolated from soil and anthills (51, 52). It should be noted, however, that the identity of these fungi has not been verified with molecular methods; the possibility that environmental strains do not always belong to the same species as the clinical strains cannot be excluded. Using ITS sequencing, Badali et al. (53) reidentified a collection of Exophiala jeanselmei clinical and environmental strains. E. jeanselmei identification was confirmed in all eumycetoma or eumycetoma-like infections, while other environmental strains were found to belong to other Exophiala species, suggesting some predilection of particular species for human invasion. Another example of possible human predilection is M. mycetomatis, which is a common agent of black-grain eumycetoma in the arid climate zones of East Africa. The direct isolation of this species from the environment is difficult (54), but its DNA has been found in soil (54), on thorns (54), and even in Hyalomma rufipes ticks (55). Recently, phylogenetic findings even suggest dung as a possible new habitat for M. mycetomatis (56).

Borelli (57) isolated a sterile fungus, reported as Madurella grisea (now known as T. grisea), from soil in Venezuela; the ecological niche and clinical potential of this rare species have not yet been determined. Also, in relatively common fungi, such as M. mycetomatis and Scedosporium species, phenotypic identification alone is not enough to determine the exact epidemiology, since these apparently similar entities might hide significant diversity (see “Taxonomy and Description of the Agents” above).

Eumycetoma may infect all people living in areas of endemicity but develops more commonly among persons who are in contact with contaminated materials, such as field workers, farmers, and fishermen. There is no obvious immune defect in eumycetoma patients, although association with some rare immune defects does occur (58–62). This concerns single-nucleotide polymorphisms in genes involved in the functioning of the host’s immune system, such as the chitinases acidic mammalian chitinase (AMCase) and chitotriosidase, complement receptor 1 (CR1), the CC chemokine ligand 5 (CCR5), the chemokines interleukin 8 (CXCL8) and interleukin 10, the interleukin receptor CXCR2, metalloproteases 2 and 9, the nitric oxide synthase NOS2, and trombospondin 4, and in the synthesis of sex hormones, such as cytochrome P450 subfamily 19 (CYP19) and catechol-O-methyltransferase (COMT) (58–62). The latter might explain why eumycetoma is more common in males than in females, as is also observed with many other opportunistic fungi.

Areas of endemicity are particularly located in tropical climate zones.M. mycetomatis is limited to semiarid to arid climates, while Falciformispora species are found in the rain forest. Locally acquired eumycetomata in temperate climates invariably are caused by S. apiospermum complex. Cases observed in the United States and Europe caused by species other than S. apiospermum are imported by immigrants from tropical countries. For example, de Hoog et al. (63) reported cases in The Netherlands originating from Indonesia and Suriname, and Ahmed et al. (20) reported M. mycetomatis eumycetoma cases seen in France but originating in Mali.

Climate has a definite influence on the prevalence and distribution of eumycetoma. Rivers that flood each year during the wet season in many countries of Africa and Asia influence the distribution of the causal agents. Rainfall also aids the spread of the etiologic agents on organic matter (64).

sect2.title: CLINICAL SIGNIFICANCE
sect2.para: Eumycetoma is a localized, chronic, noncontiguous, granulomatous infection involving cutaneous and subcutaneous tissues and eventually, in some cases, bones (65). Eumycetomata are generally confined to either the feet or the hands but occasionally affect sites such as the back, shoulders, and buttocks. Rarely, other body sites can be involved, such as the scalp, eye, jaw, and oral cavity (9, 66–68). The triad of a painless subcutaneous mass, sinuses, and discharge containing grains (masses of fungal organisms) (Fig. 2) is characteristic of eumycetoma; however, a similar condition (actinomycetoma) may be caused by aerobic actinomycete bacteria.

The disease is more commonly seen in humans than in animals. Only a few cases of eumycetoma involving animals, such as cats, dogs, horses, and goats, have been described in the literature (22, 69–73). Most cases occur in otherwise healthy patients. The development of eumycetoma after an accidental implantation of the etiologic agent following surgery (74) and in a renal transplant recipient (75) has been reported.

Eumycetoma develops after a traumatic injury by microbe-contaminated thorns, splinters, fish scales or fins, snake bites, insect bites, farm implements, and knives. The initial lesion is often characterized by a feeling of discomfort and pain at the point of inoculation. Weeks or months later, the subcutaneous tissue at the site of inoculation becomes indurated, abscesses develop, and fistulae may drain to the surface (65, 76). As described above, eumycetomata are characterized by swelling, granulomas, abscesses, and sinuses from which serosanguinous fluid containing fungal grains is discharged. Grains, which are not seen in other subcutaneous mycoses, can vary from approximately 0.2 to over 5 mm in diameter (77). The size, color, shape, and internal architecture of the grains vary depending on the etiologic agent (Table 1). Some of the host material, especially at the periphery of the grain, provides a protective barrier for the fungus against antifungal agents and against components of humoral immune responses, such as antibodies.

Eumycetoma develops slowly beneath thick fibrosclerous tissue. The subsequent phase of proliferation involves the invasion of muscles and intramuscular layers by portions of the sclerotium that break free from their parent structure. The granulomatous lesions can extend as deep as bone, where severe bone destruction, formation of small cavities, and complete remodeling may occur (65, 76). Early osteolytic damage includes loss of the cortical margin and external erosion of the bone. As the infection progresses, blood, lymphatic vessels, and nerves may be damaged. Frequently, secondary bacterial infections and osteomyelitis producing total bone destruction occur. Pain in eumycetoma is often associated with bone involvement and secondary bacterial infection.

Grains are clearly visible to the naked eye. (B) Black M. mycetomatis grain in subcutaneous tissue. Hematoxylin-eosin stain. Magnification, ×100. (C) Black E. jeanselmei grain in subcutaneous tissue. Hematoxylin-eosin stain. Magnification, ×100 (181). (D) White Fusarium verticilloides grain. Hematoxylin-eosin stain. Magnification, ×100 (182).

sect2.para: Fungus balls in preexisting lung cavities are sometimes inappropriately called eumycetomata (78, 79). In the absence of well-organized grains, they should be referred to as fungus balls, depending on the etiologic agent, e.g., aspergillomas (80). Similarly, mycelial aggregates formed by dermatophytes in cutaneous or subcutaneous tissues differ from grains of eumycetomata by lacking granule ontogeny, by presenting a distinct Splendore-Hoeppli reaction (see “Microscopy,” below) surrounding the mycelial aggregates, and by the entry of the fungus from the hair follicles into deeper tissue following the rupture of the follicular epithelium. Such infections caused by dermatophytes have been referred to as pseudomycetomata (81).

sect2.title: COLLECTION, TRANSPORT, AND STORAGE OF SPECIMENS
sect2.para: Different specimens can be obtained from patients with eumycetoma, but direct examination and culture of fungi causing eumycetoma always require surgical tissue biopsies and/or bone curettage. Tissue materials should be divided and submitted for both microbiology and histopathology and preferably molecular examination as well. It should be noted that tissue biopsy specimens without visible grains usually result in negative cultures. The best specimen for fungal culture is usually collected during surgery as an excisional or incisional biopsy specimen (82). Grains are not always present in tissue specimens obtained by a cutaneous biopsy procedure with local anesthesia. However, when they contain grains, they can also result in positive cultures. The collection of grains collected with cotton swabs from the sinus tracts is not recommended, because such grains can be contaminated or dead.

Several grains are usually needed for direct examination, culture, and DNA isolation, and therefore, as much tissue as possible should be obtained. Tissue should be collected in sterile, dry, leakproof containers and transported to the laboratory as soon as possible at room temperature. If transport is delayed for more than 2 h, specimens can be refrigerated, but care should be taken, since long storage can result in no growth. Small biopsy samples can be covered with 2 to 3 ml of sterile saline to prevent drying during transportation to the laboratory.

sect1.title: Imaging
sect1.para: Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) and radiology are often used to identify the limits of the lesions and to determine if bone is affected (82–84). Ultrasonic imaging can be used to differentiate between eumycetoma and nonmycetoma lesions and between actinomycetoma and eumycetoma lesions (82, 83, 85). In eumycetoma grains, the grains produce numerous sharp, bright hyper-reflective echoes (83, 85). When grains are more towards the surface, dermoscopy can also be used to identify grains subcutaneously. For eumycetoma caused by Acremonium sp. and T. grisea, yellowish and white structures were identified (86, 87). Subcutaneous black grains present as blue-white areas surrounded by a white halo and polymorphic vessels (88). Dermoscopy or ultrasound-guided biopsies will increase the yield of eumycetoma grains for microscopy.

sect1.title: Microscopy (Grain Appearance)
sect1.para: The grains of eumycetomata are composed of septate mycelial filaments at least 2 to 5 μm in diameter (Table 1). The mycelium may be distorted and unusual in form and size, and the cell walls of the fungi, especially toward the periphery of the grains, are thickened. Vesicles are frequently present, especially at the periphery of the grain. The mycelium of the grains may be embedded in a cement-like substance, depending on the species involved. The cement material is most likely composed of both fungal and host material. Wethered et al. (89) described the cement surrounding grains of M. mycetomatis as being an amorphous, electron-dense material with areas containing different-sized membrane-bound vesicular inclusions. M. mycetomatis grains were found to contain melanin, chitin, heavy metals, proteins, and lipids (62, 90, 91) and were surrounded by a collagen capsule (61). It was suggested that the elements composing the grains in eumycetoma may play a role in pathogenicity and resistance to antifungal agents (90–92). Often, the grains elicit an immune response, known as the Splendore-Hoeppli reaction (65, 81), seen histologically in the form of an eosinophilic deposit of amorphous material around the grain. A similar tissue reaction in experimental eumycetoma in mice has been described (93).

As shown inTable 1, grains are white or yellow-brown (white-grain eumycetoma) when the agent produces mostly hyaline mycelia, and black (black-grain eumycetoma) in the case of melanized fungi. A single proven yellow-grain fungal eumycetoma has been reported thus far, but earlier cases may have been incorrectly diagnosed as bacterial mycetomata (94). Reports of hyaline fungi such as be Acremonium (Sarocladium) kiliense or Sarocladium (formerly Acremonium) kiliense and Fusarium solani var. coeruleum forming black grains (95) are probably erroneous. Etiologic agents with melanized hyphae or conidia, such as Phaeoacremonium inflatipes and S. apiospermum, produce whitish grains in tissue (49, 96–98). Melanin production in Phaeoacremonium species is facultative, while in Scedosporium, dark pigmentation is limited to the conidia.

sect1.title: Black Grains
sect1.para: Although black grains might resemble each other, species-specific features can be noted. The color of black grains is probably caused by melanin, a high-molecular-weight compound that is anchored to extracellular proteins. In ascomycetous fungi, melanin can be produced via different melanin biosynthetic pathways, starting with different precursors. The most common pathways are the 1,8-dihydroxynaphthalene (DHN)-melanin, the 3,4-dihydroxyphenylalanine (DOPA)-melanin, and the pyomelanin biosynthetic pathways (65, 99, 100).

sect2.title: Madurella mycetomatis
sect2.para: InM. mycetomatis, melanin has been shown to be produced through the DHN-melanin and pyomelanin pathways, and it offers the fungus protection against strong oxidants and antifungal drugs (90).

In tissue, the grains produced byM. mycetomatis are reddish brown to black (Fig. 2A and B). They may reach 5 mm or more in diameter and are firm to hard. In tissue sections, the grains are compact, variable in size and shape, and frequently multilobulated. They are composed of hyphae 1.2 to 5 μm in diameter that terminate in enlarged hyphal cells at the periphery of the grains, which measure 12 to 15 μm in diameter. The cell wall pigment is minimal, but hyphal cells contain brown particles. The hyphae are embedded in a conspicuous brown matrix that is characteristic of M. mycetomatis. Within the cement material, proteins of both the host and the pathogen can be found (61, 101–103). The cement material is absent in early grains (101, 104). In experimental models, four different steps in grain formation were noted, which include (i) the recognition of pathogen and host, (ii) crosslinking of host cells and pathogens to form the early grain, (iii) degranulation of host cells and generation of reactive oxygen species, and (iv) melanization of the grain (101). Cement material is formed only in the last stage. Within a single lesion, the grains might be in different developmental stages. Some grains are vesicular and more regular in size and shape. The vesicles are predominantly visible in the peripheral zone in a dense, brown, cement-like matrix (105).

sect2.title: Falciformispora Species
sect2.para: Melanin inF. senegalensis is produced through the DHN-, DOPA-, and pyomelanin pathways, while F. tompkinsii produces melanin via the DHN-melanin pathway only (100). The grains of the two Falciformispora species that cause mycetoma are indistinguishable from each other (77) and are difficult to distinguish from the grains of T. grisea (82). They are black, 0.5 to 2 mm in size, and firm to hard. In tissue sections, the grains are round to polylobulated, with large vesicles. At the periphery, the mycelium is embedded in a black, cement-like substance. The central portion of each grain is nonpigmented and consists of a loose network of hyphae (77, 106). Although it is quite difficult to distinguish Falciformispora grains from those of T. grisea, the borders of F. senegalensis grains are less even and more crenelated and the peripheral zones show larger vesicles and a more irregular hyphal arrangement (106).

sect2.title: Trematosphaeria grisea
sect2.para: T. grisea produces melanin via the DHN-melanin pathway (100). Grains of T. grisea are black, 0.3 to 0.6 mm in diameter, and soft to firm. In tissue sections, the grains resemble those of Falciformispora species and are oval, lobulated, or reniform (kidney shaped), and sometimes vermiform (worm shaped) (106). They are composed of a dense network of hyphae that are weakly pigmented in the center and brown to blackish brown in the peripheral region as the result of the presence of a brown, cement-like interstitial material (77, 82, 106).

sect2.title: Medicopsis romeroi
sect2.para: M. romeroi forms its melanin via the DHN-, DOPA-, and pyomelanin pathways (100). It produces soft to firm black sclerotia that are oval, lobulated, sometimes vermiform, and about 1.0 mm in diameter. They resemble those of T. grisea (107).

sect2.title: Curvularia geniculata
sect2.para: C. geniculata grains are black to dark brown, firm, and 0.5 to 1.0 mm or more in size (77). In tissue sections, grains are spherical, ovoid, or irregularly shaped and are often surrounded by a zone of epithelioid cells. The periphery of the grain is a dense, interwoven mass of dematiaceous mycelium and thick-walled, chlamydospore-like cells embedded in a cement-like substance (77). The interior of the grains is vacuolar and consists of a loose network of septate, hyphal filaments. The grains of Curvularia lunata resemble those of C. geniculata in their morphologic characteristics (77).

sect2.title: Exophiala jeanselmei
sect2.para: In host tissue,E. jeanselmei produces dark brown to black grains that are irregular in shape and fragile (Fig. 2C). Detached portions or fragments of the grains often are found within giant cells (77). When extruded through fistulae, the grains often look like worms (vermiform) because of their elongated shapes and irregular surfaces (77). In tissue sections, grains appear as hollow structures or as sinuous bands that are vermiform. The external surface is composed of brown, thick-walled hyphae and thick-walled chlamydospore-like cells. The grains are cement free. Within the hollow grains, smaller, degenerated hyphal fragments with leukocytes and giant cells may be seen (77).

sect1.title: White Grains
sect1.para: Grains ofScedosporium species and Fusarium species are histopathologically similar and almost impossible to distinguish from each other (108). However, there are some features that might help in recognizing individual organisms (109).

sect2.title: Scedosporium Species
sect2.para: Grains ofScedosporium species in tissue are white to yellowish white and soft to firm; they vary from globose to subglobose or lobulated and are 0.2 to 2.0 mm in diameter (77). They are composed of hyaline hyphae 1.5 to 5.0 μm in diameter that radiate from the center into terminal thick-walled cells 15 to 20 μm in diameter at the peripheries. The central portion of each grain consists of loosely interwoven hyaline mycelium, and some vesicles can be noted (109).

sect2.title: Fusarium Species
sect2.para: The grains ofFusarium spp. (Fig. 2D) are white to pale yellow, soft, and 0.2 to 0.5 mm in diameter. They are composed of slender, polymorphic, septate hyphae 1.5 to 2.0 μm in diameter with irregular bulbous swellings and peripheral cementing material (77, 109).

sect2.title: Neotestudina rosatii
sect2.para: The sclerotia ofN. rosatii are white to brownish white, 0.5 to 1.0 mm in diameter, and soft. In tissue sections, the sclerotia appear to be polyhedral to subregular and consist of hyphae, which are embedded in the peripheral cementing material. The grains demonstrate an eosinophilic border. The central portion of each grain consists of more or less disintegrated mycelium and chlamydospores (77).

sect2.title: Phaeoacremonium Species
sect2.para: AlthoughPhaeoacremonium is a dematiaceous fungus and a well-known agent of phaeohyphomycosis, it seems that melanin production is facultative in eumycetoma. White-grain eumycetoma caused by P. krajdenii has been reported by Hemashettar et al. (110).

sect1.title: Nucleic Acid Detection
sect1.para: Molecular diagnostics have been developed for selected agents. However, most of these molecular assays have been used for culture identification. Only recently, methods have been developed to isolate DNA directly from fungal grains ofM. mycetomatis. To isolate DNA directly from fungal grains, 2-mm metal beads are added to isolated grains and treated in a Bead-Beater for 2 min. DNA is isolated from the lysate with either the DNeasy plant minikit (Qiagen) or the ZR fungal/bacterial DNA miniprep kit (Zymo Research) (111). The DNA quantity and quality obtained with this isolation method are adequate for any of the molecular identification assays developed and listed in the section “Molecular Identification” of this chapter, below.

sect2.title: ISOLATION PROCEDURES
sect2.para: To maximize the chances of obtaining pure cultures of the etiologic agents, grains from eumycotic eumycetomata should be washed several times with saline containing antibacterial antibiotics, such as penicillin and streptomycin (83). The grains are then cultured on Sabouraud’s glucose agar (SGA) containing chloramphenicol (50 mg/liter) and SGA containing chloramphenicol and cycloheximide (500 mg/liter) in petri dishes. When Scedosporium spp. are suspected, the use of semiselective plates such as Dichloran Rose Bengal Chloramphenicol agar or Mycosel agar could be considered (37). Plates should be incubated at 25 and 37°C. Because many of the fungi that cause eumycetoma grow slowly, culture plates should be incubated for 6 weeks before being discarded as negative. Identification of the isolated fungus is based on gross morphology of fruiting bodies and conidia, if present.

sect1.title: Morphological Identification
sect1.para: The mycological identification of most of the fungi causing eumycetoma can be achieved by studying the morphological characteristics described below and inchapters 123, 124, 127, and 128 of this Manual. For additional morphological features and simplified identification keys, readers are referred to specialized references such as the Atlas of Clinical Fungi (15). One should be careful when relying solely on morphological features. Many misidentifications have occurred in the past. Currently, molecular identification tools have been proven to be the most reliable in species identification (17).

sect2.title: Madurella mycetomatis
sect2.para: In culture,M. mycetomatis shows wide variation. Colonies are slow growing and white at first, becoming olivaceous, yellow, or brown; flat or dome-shaped; and velvety to glabrous, often with a rust-brown diffusible pigment (Fig. 1A). M. tropicana, M. pseudomycetomatis, and M. fahalii are indistinguishable from M. mycetomatis. The optimal growth temperature for M. fahalii, M. tropicana, and M. pseudomycetomatis is 30°C, and that for M. mycetomatis 37°C (5). On minimal media (90), sclerotial bodies 750 μm in diameter develop for M. mycetomatis. These are black and consist of undifferentiated polygonal cells (Fig. 1B). On SGA, the mycelium is sterile. On nutritionally poor media, such as soil extract or hay infusion agar, about 50% of the isolates produce round to pyriform conidia 3 to 4 μm in diameter at the tips of phialides (77). The phialides are tapering, ranging from 3 to 15 μm in length, often with an inconspicuous collarette (Fig. 1C).

sect2.title: Falciformispora Species
sect2.para: F. senegalensis and F. tompkinsii grow rapidly and produce gray-brown colonies (Fig. 1D). The optimal growth temperature for F. senegalensis is 33°C, and that for F. tompkinsii is 36°C (14). On cornmeal agar, both species produce ascostromata that are nonostiolate (without natural opening), scattered, immersed or superficial, globose to subglobose, black, and covered with brown, smoothly bent hyphae (Fig. 1E). The asci, produced after prolonged incubation on plant stems, are eight-spored, clavate to cylindrical, and double walled. The major difference between the two species is found in the ascospores, which differ in size, shape, septation, and the nature of the gelatinous sheath that surrounds them (18, 112) (Fig. 1F).

sect2.title: Trematosphaeria grisea
sect2.para: T. grisea forms slow-growing, velvety colonies that are cerebriform, radially furrowed or smooth, and dark gray to olive brown to black (Fig. 1G). The reverses of the colonies are black. The optimal growth temperature is 30°C, and no growth is observed at 37°C (14). Microscopically, the hyphae are septate, light to dark brown, 1 to 3 μm in diameter, and nonsporulating. Chlamydospores are rare. Large moniliform hyphae, 3 to 5 μm in diameter, are often present. Some isolates of T. grisea have been described as producing abortive or fertile pycnidia (107, 113). Such isolates are morphologically indistinguishable from N. mackinnonii (114, 115), but rRNA ITS sequence data (1) show large differences between these species. Furthermore, the optimal growth temperature of N. mackinnonii is 24°C, which is lower than that of T. grisea (14). Environmental isolates of T. grisea are rapid growing and produce conidiomata (pycnidia) after 8 weeks of incubation (Fig. 1I).

sect2.title: Medicopsis romeroi
sect2.para: Colonies ofM. romeroi are fast growing and floccose to velvety, with a gray surface and whitish margin. The reverse of the colony is black, with no diffusible pigment. The optimal growth temperature is 33°C (14). On nutritionally deficient media such as oatmeal agar under near-UV light, pycnidia develop after 3 to 4 weeks (14). The pycnidia are subglobose, 80 to 160 μm in diameter, and dark brick to fawn, later becoming dark brown with short necks. They are ostiolate (with a natural opening), and setae around ostioles are septate and roughened and measure 80 to 100 by 3 μm. The conidiophores inside the conidiomata are sparse and have lateral branches. Conidiogenous cells are hyaline and are borne on branches, or arise directly from cells lining the conidiomatal cavity which produce hyaline to yellowish, short, cylindrical conidia measuring 1 to 2 by 1.0 μm (14).

sect2.title: Scedosporium spp.
sect2.para: Scedosporium fungi will grow without difficulty on standard mycological media such as Sabouraud’s dextrose agar or potato dextrose agar (37). Semiselective media in which either benomyl, cycloheximide, or dichloran are incorporated, such as Dichloran Rose Bengal Chloramphenicol medium or Mycoselagar, can be used to select for growth of Scedosporium spp. (37). The colonies of S. apiospermum and S. boydii are indistinguishable from each other (37). Scedosporium colonies grow rapidly and are floccose and white at first, becoming gray as conidia are produced. With age, the colonies become dark grayish brown. Submerged ascocarps (cleistothecia) may be produced when isolates are grown on cornmeal agar and are visible macroscopically as small black dots. They are globose, nonostiolate, 100 to 300 μm in diameter (37), and often covered with brown, thick-walled, septate hyphae 2 to 3 μm wide. They have a wall 4 to 6 μm thick that is composed of two or three layers of interwoven, flattened, dark brown cells, each 2 to 6 μm wide. The cleistothecia open at maturity by an irregular rupture of the wall. The eight-spored asci are ellipsoidal to nearly spherical and 12 to 18 by 9 to 13 μm. The ascospores are ellipsoidal to oblate, are symmetrical or slightly flattened, measure 6 to 9 by 3.5 to 6.0 μm, are straw colored, and have two germ pores. The anamorph produces conidia that are oval to clavate, truncate, and subhyaline, becoming pale gray to pale brown in masses. Conidia are produced singly and are 5 to 7 by 4 to 6 μm in size for S. apiospermum and 4 to 9 by 6 to 10 μm for S. boydii (37). They remain attached at the tips of annellides. Annellations can be detected at the tips of conidiogenous cells as swollen rings. Some isolates also produce a graphium-like anamorph, which is characterized by rope-like bundles of hyphae with annellidic conidiogenesis. The hyphae are fused into long stalks known as synnemata. The conidia produced are hyaline, cylindric to clavate, and truncate at the base. A fungus consisting of elongate, multicellular conidia and described as Polycytella hominis (116) was recently proven to be a degenerate anamorph of S. boydii (117).

sect2.title: Neotestudina rosatii
sect2.para: Colonies ofN. rosatii are slow growing, attaining diameters of 25 to 28 mm in 2 weeks, and have an aerial mycelium that is grayish black to brownish black (Fig. 1J). On potato-carrot or cornmeal agar incubated at 30°C, most of the ascomata are submerged (Fig. 1K). The ascostromal walls are smooth and are surrounded by interwoven, brown to hyaline hyphae. The eight-spored asci, 12 to 35 by 10 to 25 μm, are scattered in the central part of the ascostroma (Fig. 1L) and are globose to subglobose, thick walled, and bitunicate, becoming evanescent as the ascospores mature. The ascospores vary in size (9 to 12.5 by 4.5 to 8.0 μm) and shape, ranging from ellipsoidal to rhomboidal, asymmetrical, or slightly curved; they are constricted at the median transverse septum and have brown, smooth walls.

sect1.title: Assimilation Patterns
sect1.para: To discriminate fungi causing mycetoma only on the basis of morphological features is difficult. Therefore, some biochemical analyses can be performed to aid in the identification (Table 2). For S. apiospermum and S. boydii, this has been done with the Taxa Profile Micronaut assay from Marlin Diagnostika; however, no clear discrimination between the two species was noted (118). With respect to growth temperatures, both S. apiospermum and S. boydii grow well at 40°C but not at 45°C (37).

table.title: TABLE 2 Assimilation patterns of species causing eumycotic eumycetoma

sect1.para: aData from reference 14. Results were positive (+), negative (−), weak (W), positive or negative (+/−), negative or positive (−/+), or not done (ND).

It is known thatM. mycetomatis grows better at 37°C than at 30°C, with a maximum of 40°C, whereas T. grisea grows better at 30°C than at 37°C. M. mycetomatis is slowly proteolytic and utilizes glucose, maltose, and galactose but not sucrose. It utilizes potassium nitrate, ammonium sulfate, asparagine, and urea, and it hydrolyzes starch. T. grisea, on the other hand, is weakly proteolytic and assimilates glucose, maltose, and sucrose but not lactose (Table 2).

The pleosporalean eumycetoma-causative agentsF. senegalensis, F. tompkinsii, T. grisea, M. romeroi, N. mackinnonii, and Pseudochaetosphaeronema larense all are able to assimilate D-galactose, D-saccharose, N-acetylglucosamine, D-cellobiose, D-raffinose, D-maltose, D-trehalose, D-mannitol, L-rhamnose, D-melezitose, palatinose, and D-glucose but not DL-lactate, potassium gluconate, sodium glucuronate, and glucosamine (14). F. senegalensis does not assimilate potassium 2-ketogluconate, erythritol, or D-melibiose, whereas F. tompkinsii, T. grisea, M. romeroi, N. mackinnonii, and P. larense do (14). Furthermore, F. senegalensis is able to assimilate D-lactose, whereas the majority of the pleosporalean eumycetoma-causative agents do not. F. tompkinsii is the only species that does not assimilate inositol and sorbitol (14). M. romeroi is the only species that does not assimilate methyl-D-glucopyranoside, and N. mackinnonii is susceptible to cycloheximide and able to assimilate D-xylose (14).

sect1.title: Molecular Identification
sect1.para: Currently the gold standard for species identification of all fungi is sequencing of the ITS region—the primary fungal DNA barcode—with primers V9G and LS266. Identification is then performed either by Sanger sequencing (119), by restriction fragment length polymorphism analysis (21), or by using rolling-circle amplification (RCA) (120, 121), all of which are more reliable than identification based on culture (17). Padlock probes for RCA have been developed for M. mycetomatis (120), M. pseudomycetomatis (120), M. fahalii (120), M. tropicana, F. senegalensis (120), F. tompkinsii (120), T. grisea (120), M. romeroi (120), S. boydii (121, 122), and S. apiospermum (122).

Molecular assays that can directly identify the causative agent were also developed for some species. ForM. mycetomatis (21, 123), M. pseudomycetomatis (11), and S. apiospermum (124–127), species-specific PCRs have been developed which can be directly performed on DNA isolated from infected tissue. These PCRs were based on the ITS region or on specific regions identified by sequencing specific genomic fragments. Currently, the M. mycetomatis-specific PCR developed by Ahmed et al. is most widely used (21). However, recently it was demonstrated that this PCR gives rise to a PCR product of another size with M. pseudomycetomatis (11, 123). The other PCR developed in the same paper cross-reacted with M. tropicana, M. fahalii, and M. pseudomycetomatis, species not described at the time that PCR was developed (11). The primers developed by Lim et al. seemed more specific, as no cross-reaction was noted with any of the other eumycetoma-causative agents (123).

In contrast to classical PCRs, which are visualized on a gel, real-time PCRs were developed forMadurella and Scedosporium species (128, 129). For M. mycetomatis and M. fahalii, species-specific primers were designed on the ITS region (128). A real-time multiplex assay has been developed to differentiate M. mycetomatis, M. pseudomycetomatis, M. tropicana, and M. fahalii (128). Further, isothermal amplification techniques, including loop-mediated amplification (LAMP) (111, 130, 131) and recombinase polymerase amplification (RPA) (111), have been developed for M. mycetomatis and S. apiospermum. Of these isothermal amplification techniques, the RPA had a lower detection limit than LAMP, and fewer false-negative reactions were observed (111).

sect2.title: MALDI-TOF MS
sect2.para: Matrix-assisted laser desorption ionization–time of flight mass spectrometry (MALDI-TOF MS) has been used to identify black grain eumycetoma-causative agents andScedosporium spp. The VITEK MS v3.2 database for the bioMérieux VITEK MS contains spectra for the occasional causative agent S. boydii and the rare causative agents Aspergillus flavus, Aspergillus fumigatus, Aspergillus nidulans, Cladophialophora bantiana, Fusarium oxysporum, Fusarium solani, Microsporum audouinii, Microsporum canis, and Scedosporium apiospermum, but not the common causative agent M. mycetomatis and the occasional causative agents F. senegalensis, T. grisea, M. romeroi, and N. mackinnonii. The Bruker filamentous fungal library version 4.0 from the Bruker MALDI Biotyper does not contain the most common causative agents of black grain human eumycetoma (132). It does contain S. boydii and S. apiospermum, the most common causative agents of white grain eumycetoma. Fraser et al. constructed a database for the Bruker MALDI Biotyper able to identify all 50 isolates of M. mycetomatis, F. senegalensis, M. romeroi, N. mackinnonii, E. grisea, E. paragrisea, M. fahalii, and R. rufulum when using a MALDI-TOF log score of >1.8, and 33 isolates when using a log score of >2.0 (133). The identification of Scedosporium spp. by the Bruker MALDI Biotyper was also improved when spectra from local strains were included in the database (134, 135).

sect2.title: TYPING SYSTEMS
sect2.para: Over the years, many molecular typing techniques have been established for a number of fungal species, including those causing eumycetoma. Such techniques are useful not only in genotyping but also in accurate species identification (21). Genotyping enables differentiation of environmental and clinical isolates, and therefore it is an important tool in understanding the environmental distribution of species and source of infection. For M. mycetomatis, several typing techniques have been developed over the years, including random amplified polymorphic DNA (RAPD) (136, 137), restriction endonuclease assay (REA) (137), amplified fragment length polymorphism (AFLP) (138), variable number tandem repeat (VNTR) (138), and the short tandem repeat assay MmySTR (139). Of these techniques, MmySTR was found to be stable, reproducible, and specific and had the highest diversity index (139). An AFLP was also developed for M. pseudomycetomatis (11).

ForS. boydii and S. apiospermum, web-based multilocus sequence typing (MLST) assays have been developed (https://mlst.mycologylab.org) (140). Subspecific typing of S. apiospermum at the population level is not problematic, because of the large degree of heterogeneity. Rainer et al. (141) found with M-13 fingerprinting, a PCR-based typing system in which the core sequence of phage M13 is used as a single primer, that nearly all strains analyzed belonged to different genotypes; several genotypes were recovered from a single sampling site. The high degree of polymorphism enabled Zouhair et al. (142) to monitor the dissemination of a strain colonizing the lungs of a patient with cystic fibrosis to cutaneous locations by using multilocus enzyme electrophoresis and randomly amplified polymorphic DNA. In a longitudinal study, Defontaine et al. (143) analyzed nine patients with cystic fibrosis, none of whom were found to harbor strains that shared the same genotype.

sect1.title: (1→3)-β-D-Glucan Detection
sect1.para: There are currently no specific commercially available antigen tests for detecting any of the eumycetoma-causative agents, but the panfungal (1→3)-β-D-glucan detection assay could be of use to monitor disease progression (see chapter 120 of this Manual). (1→3)-β-D-glucan has been detected in serum of eumycetoma patients (144). Unfortunately, since (1→3)-β-D-glucan is panfungal, it cannot discriminate between the different causative agents (144). Furthermore, it also cannot discriminate between actinomycetoma and eumycetoma, as (1→3)-β-D-glucan has been detected in serum from both types (144).

sect1.title: In-House-Made Antibody Detection Methods
sect1.para: Antibody detection tests created in-house have been used in some locations where eumycetoma is endemic (145–149); these include immunodiffusion, counter-immunoelectrophoresis (CIE), and enzyme-linked immunosorbent assays (ELISAs) using crude antigens prepared from fungal hyphae (83) or recombinant proteins, such as the M. mycetomatis translationally controlled tumor protein, fructose bisphosphate aldolase, and pyruvate kinase (102, 103, 115, 150). Immunodiffusion could discriminate between eumycetomas due to M. mycetomatis and actinomycetoma (146). The ELISA developed by Wethered et al. (148) for M. mycetomatis cytoplasmic antigens could clearly differentiate between patients and healthy controls based on IgM antibody responses, but when this ELISA was repeated by Zaini et al. (150), no differentiation between patients and healthy controls was obtained. The clinical value of all of these in-house serological tests is hampered by lack of standardized antigen preparations, sensitivity, and specificity, and therefore none of them is still in use.

Recently, three immunodominant proteins of 45 kDa, 60 kDa, and 95 kDa with high specificity forM. mycetomatis were identified in a cytoplasmatic extract of M. mycetomatis (145). This preparation was tested with 100 patients in Sudan, but clinical use of this assay still needs to be evaluated (145). Of all the assays described, CIE was deemed most reliable and was used for many years by the Mycetoma Research Centre in Khartoum, Sudan, as a routine diagnostic tool, until problems with the reproducibility of the antigen preparation ended use of this assay.

ForS. boydii and S. apiospermum, a specific monoclonal antibody recognizing a 120-kDa extracellular antigen located in the spore and hyphal walls has been generated that enables species identification (151). Furthermore, two recombinant proteins corresponding to S. boydii catalase A1 (CatA1) and S. boydii cytosolic Cu,Zn-superoxide dismutase (SODC) were able to detect antibodies generated during a respiratory infection in cystic fibrosis patients (152). It is still to be determined whether these recombinant antigens are also able to detect antibodies in eumycetoma patients.

sect1.title: In Vitro Susceptibility Testing
sect1.para: For most of the eumycetoma-causative agents,in vitro susceptibility assays based on the M38A protocol of the Clinical and Laboratory Standards Institute (CLSI) have been used (92). These either were in-house assays (153–159) or used the commercial YeastOne testing panel (159–161). For some of the causative agents, such as the nonsporulating Madurella species, adaptation of these protocols was required to perform in vitro susceptibility testing with hyphal fragments instead of conidia (92). This consisted of generation of hyphal fragments by either sonication (153) or bead-beating with glass beads (162) and the use of viability dyes such as XTT (153, 154, 157) and resazurin (163). When using the resazurin derivative alamar blue, the pyomelanin secreted by M. mycetomatis did not influence visual endpoint reading; however, it resulted in a loss in the resorufin peak when read spectrophotometrically (161).

Recently, as well as these microdilution-based methods, disk diffusion, E-testing, and VIP check have also been used (162). Comparable MICs (MICs within a 2-dilution-step difference) between microdilution and E-testing for itraconazole and posaconazole were obtained for 80% and 90% of the isolates tested, respectively (162).

When using microdilution assays, with the exception ofM. fahalii, Madurella species have in general low minimal inhibitory concentrations (MICs) for the azoles ketoconazole (11, 157, 159), itraconazole (11, 157, 159), posaconazole (11, 157), voriconazole (11, 157, 159), isavuconazole (155), and ravuconazole (154) and the orotomide olorofim (156). Higher MICs have been obtained for the azole fluconazole (11, 157, 159), the polyene amphotericin B (153, 159, 160), and terbinafine (157).

For the pleosporalean fungi,F. senegalensis, F. tompkinsii, T. grisea, M. romeroi, N. mackinnonii, E. grisea, and E. paragrisea, in general 10 times higher MICs for the azoles are reported. For terbinafine, the opposite was noted. F. senegalensis and M. romeroi had in general 10-fold lower MICs for terbinafine than M. mycetomatis (164).

None of the eumycetoma-causative agents was susceptible to the echinocandins or 5-flucytosine (Table 3). In vitro, no difference was noted when itraconazole was combined with either terbinafine or olorofim (156, 165).

Thein vitro susceptibility assay for M. mycetomatis has also been used in the open source drug-discovery program MycetOS (https://github.com/OpenSourceMycetoma/General-Start-Here), in which currently more than 1,200 drug-like compounds have been screened (166).

sect1.title: In Vivo Animal Models
sect1.para: There is currently a large gap between thein vitro susceptibility data and clinical outcome. Only seven studies have tested the efficacy of antifungal agents against eumycetoma in animals: five in the invertebrate Galleria mellonella (164, 166–168) and two in mice (169, 170). In all in vivo models, M. mycetomatis was the causative agent studied (164, 168–170). In these studies, it was demonstrated that although M. mycetomatis was highly susceptible in vitro to azole antifungal agents, in vivo therapeutic efficacy was found only for ravuconazole (164) and bitertanol (166), whereas no therapeutic efficacy was demonstrated for ketoconazole (168), itraconazole (167, 168, 170), or voriconazole (168). The therapeutic efficacy of posaconazole was concentration dependent (166, 168), and that from luliconazole and eberconazole was time dependent (164). Although higher MICs have been obtained for amphotericin B and terbinafine, these antifungal agents showed better therapeutic efficacy in larvae of G. mellonella (167, 168) and mice (170). Combining amphotericin B, terbinafine, or itraconazole was antagonistic in G. mellonella larvae (167).

Of the new drugs identified in the open source drug discovery program MycetOS, fenbendazole (164), olorofim (164), MMV006357 (166), MMV675968 (166), MMV022478 (166), and the fenarimol analogues EPL-BS0178 (166), EPL-BS0495 (166), and EPL-BS1025 (166) prolonged larval survival.

So far, no clear correlation between IC50 or MIC50 and in vivo efficacy in the G. mellonella larval model was found (92). This might be due to the difference between a hyphal inoculum and the presence of grains in tissue (92). For M. mycetomatis, it has been demonstrated that adding isolated M. mycetomatis melanin, a key component of black grains, results in a 4 to 5 2-fold-dilution-step increase in MIC for ketoconazole and itraconazole (90). For the fenarimol compounds, the logDvalue at pH 7.4 was more indicative than the IC50 or MIC50 (166).

sect1.title: Clinical Studies
sect1.para: The management and prognosis of actinomycetoma differ from those of eumycetoma. Actinomycetoma is treated with antimicrobial therapy only, with a high success rate. Eumycetoma is treated with a combination of antifungal therapy and surgery, with limited success (171).

Currently there are no linked data between MICs obtained for any of the causative agents and clinical outcome. Furthermore, since surgery is always a component of eumycetoma treatment, direct comparison between MIC and outcome might be complicated (92). Only limited patient-based studies have been performed to determine the outcome of antifungal treatment, and studies comparing different antifungal agents with clinical outcome are lacking. The first large clinical study to determine the therapeutic efficacy of itraconazole and fosravuconazole only started in 2017, and currently, no data are available from this study (172). Nevertheless, in summarizing the few published studies, we can draw some conclusions. In the case of M. mycetomatis eumycetoma, ketoconazole resulted in cure of only 5 out of 13 patients (173), a finding which was confirmed when a cohort of 571 patients treated with 200 to 400 mg of ketoconazole was followed. In that cohort, only 321 (56.2%) of patients were cured, and 35 (6.1%) underwent amputation (92, 174). Since ketoconazole is now no longer approved for the treatment of fungal diseases, itraconazole has become the recommended antifungal agent (175, 176). In the few studies performed with this drug, itraconazole resulted in cure of only 1 patient out of 13, while the rest of the patients either had stable lesions or improved (177). All 23 patients receiving itraconazole together with trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole and surgery were cured (178). However, with newer azoles, such as posaconazole, better outcomes have been achieved (179). Negroni and his group treated six eumycetoma patients with posaconazole; they were able to cure four patients, and the other two either were clinically improved or had stable eumycetoma lesion (179). The only non-azole drug thatwas evaluated clinically for treatment of eumycetoma is terbinafine. In the study by N’diaye et al., 20 patients were treated with terbinafine; 4 were cured, 12 showed clinical improvement, and 4 showed no effect (180). In the study by Sow et al., in which terbinafine was combined with surgery, it was demonstrated that out of the 22 patients for whom data were available until the end of treatment, 20 (90.9%) of patients were cured and 2 (9.1%) had a recurrence (178).

In terms of drug discovery and drug development for eumycetoma, fosravuconazole is currently being explored in a large clinical trial (172). Fosravuconazole is a prodrug of ravuconazole, and M. mycetomatis appeared to be highly susceptible to this drug in vitro (154); unfortunately the outcome of this trial is currently still unknown.

sect2.title: EVALUATION, INTERPRETATION, AND REPORTING OF RESULTS
sect2.para: Because agents of eumycotic eumycetoma are soil or plant saprobes, their etiologic role in mycetoma must be carefully established. A definitive diagnosis is based on the demonstration of grains in tissue, which are expelled through draining sinuses. Grains may become entangled in gauze bandages placed over fistulae. Pus, exudate, or biopsy material should be examined for the presence of grains that are detectable with the naked eye. Their color, internal architecture, size, and shape give a fair indication of the identity of the possible etiologic agents, but molecular identification tools are often needed for final identification. With the generation of DNA isolation techniques that can now be performed directly on isolated grains from the lesion, time to identification can be shortened considerably.

When no molecular identification tools can be used, actinomycotic mycetomata can be differentiated from eumycotic eumycetomata by the examination of crushed, Gram-stained grains. Actinomycotic grains, as well as coccoid and bacillary forms, are composed of Gram-positive, interwoven, thin filaments, 0.5 to 1.0 μm in diameter. Grains of the eumycotic agents, on the other hand, are composed of broader, interwoven, septate hyphae, 2 to 5 μm in diameter, with many unusually shaped, swollen cells up to 15 μm in diameter, especially at the periphery of the grains. In many species, the grains are embedded in cement-like material. The differentiation between actinomycetoma and eumycetoma can at least lead to indication of proper therapy, namely antibiotic treatment for actinomycetoma and a combination of antifungal therapy and surgery for eumycetoma.

Now that it has become apparent that there are differences in susceptibility of the causative agents and that as more antifungal drugs become available, a definitive identification of the etiologic agent based on molecular identification, MALDI-TOF, or culture should be made. Careful evaluation of culture results is important, especially when new or uncommon fast-growing species are reported, since some of these species might represent contamination during collection of specimens or isolation.
